utterances: Utility companies have been fighting the new regulation.
They say it could cause economic hardship and higher energy costs.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
For years, animal rights groups in Europe have tried to get Spain to ban bullfighting.
Now, American rodeo promoters are offering an alternative.
Dozens of America's top rodeo cowboys have taken their show to Europe.
The tour is starting at Spanish bullfighting rings.
Jerome Socolovsky went out to a show to see how the rodeo was playing in Spain.
(Soundbite of rodeo)
(Soundbite of music)
A bilingual emcee tries to fire up the crowd in the municipal bullring of Guadalajara, a small city near Madrid.
(Soundbite of motorcycles)
Out come the Harley-Davidsons with Miss Rodeos waving the stars and stripes, and then the cowboys rope steer and ride broncos as the high decibel sound system shakes the foundations of the arena.
Here in the bull ring, you normally find crowds watching in silence as matadors face down bulls in a fight to the death.
This is something completely different, and it sure is a culture shock for many of the people here.
An elderly lady with a perfect hairdo sits primly, clutching a purse on her lap.
(Spanish spoken).
This is very odd, says Josefina Palafox, who didn't plan to be here.
She and a senior friend were just out for an evening stroll.
(Spanish spoken).
And we saw the commotion and decided to see what it was all about, she says.
It's very American, she adds, and we like it.
Well, not quite.
The friend, Conchita Ruza, is not so keen.
(Spanish spoken).
First of all, you don't have all this racket.
Secondly, the bull is a beautiful animal.
And lastly, she says, I'm Spanish.
(Soundbite of rodeo)
Unidentified Man #1: (Spanish spoken)
Yeehaw.
Unidentified Man #1: Yeah.
(Unintelligible).
(Soundbite of cheering)
The crowd enthusiastically takes part in a yeehaw contest.
But outside the ring, there's been criticism of the rodeo.
One commentator in El Mundo newspaper argued that rodeos in Spain are as culturally misplaced as recent efforts to bring bullfighting to the U.S.
Still, these rodeos celebrate a facet of Americana that European cultural snobs love to sneer at: the flag-waving, the country music, and everywhere, there are cowboys in 10-gallon hats.
Hi, how you doing?
Good, how are you?
My name's Jerome Socolovsky.
I'm with National Public Radio in the U.S.
Oh, cool.
Mike Beers from Oregon.
I'm a world champion team roper from the States, and I come over here for the month we're over here.
He thinks the rodeo will be a hit in Spain.
Increasing numbers of people tell pollsters here that they feel queasy about bulls being killed in the ring.
You know, they're used to seeing the bull, when they get done with him here, they drag him out on a sled.
We rope the steer by the feet here.
We get done with him, he jumps up and runs out of the arena.
The crowd loves it.
(Shouting) Yeehaw.
These children are more accustomed to shouting ole at bullfighters, but 10-year-old Alba Perez says she loves animals and now prefers the rodeo.
(Spanish spoken).
Because they do more stuff, she says, and they don't kill the bull.
(Soundbite of music)
The rodeo may have its origins in the American West at a time when it belonged to Spain, but this spectacle couldn't be more un-Spanish, and that's a big part of its appeal here.
For NPR News, I'm Jerome Socolovsky in Guadalajara, Spain.
(Soundbite of music)
Unidentified Man #2: (Singing) (Unintelligible).
We go now to Minneapolis where this morning divers will try again to retrieve those still missing after a bridge collapsed on Wednesday.
Water currents in the Mississippi River have been so dangerous that the search had to be stopped yesterday even before it got dark.
Authorities say that as many as 30 people may still be missing.
The official death toll now stands at five.
Minnesota officials also acknowledged that they were warned as early as 1990 that the eight-lane bridge had been labeled structurally deficient.
From Minneapolis, NPR's David Schaper reports.

Investigators are still far from being certain about what caused the Interstate 35W Bridge over the Mississippi River to collapse Wednesday night, but it's becoming abundantly clear that the bridge had been in poor shape for some time.
In 1990, it was classified as a structurally deficient bridge.
Minnesota state bridge engineer Dan Dorgan says federal inspectors designated the bridge as such because of significant corrosion in its bearings.
And he says in the mid-1990s additional inspections found fatigue cracks.
Again in 2005, the federal government rated the I-35W Bridge as structurally deficient, but apparently it wasn't a cause for alarm.
According to transportation officials, the I-35W Bridge was one of 77,000 bridges in that category nationwide.
Dan Dorgon says the state did some repairs over the years and stepped up inspections of the bridge, but he says those inspections did not find the need to replace the bridge was immediate.
We thought we had done all we could.
Obviously something went terribly wrong.
Minnesota's Governor Tim Pawlenty is now ordering emergency inspections of all bridges in the state of similar design.

National Transportation Safety Board investigators say they can't yet determine if structural difficulties caused the bridge to collapse, but they are getting important clues in their investigation from Army Corps of Engineers security cameras that taped the horrific event.
In addition, NTSB chairman Mark Rosenker says new technology allows investigators to use a computer model to more rapidly do a failure analysis of the bridge.
This program, along with the video, is going to probably improve the ability for the NTSB to get the facts, to do its analysis, by months.
In the meantime, divers continued to try to search through the murky Mississippi River water yesterday to recover victims whose bodies might be trapped in cars or within the twisted wreckage.
But Hennepin County sheriff Rich Stanek, whose office is coordinating the dives, says the task is a difficult one.
The divers are facing some treacherous conditions in terms of the debris, the structure, the concrete, the rebar, the water conditions themselves.
You know, any time you dive in the Mississippi River is not a great idea.
And then you've got some unknown currents now because water is going under the bridge.
Stanek says that authorities lowered the water level of the river from nine feet to seven feet by restricting the amount of water flowing through an upriver dam.
But that too created dangerous changes in river current, thwarting some recovery efforts.
Stanek and other officials met with families whose loved ones are still missing.
Eighteen-year-old Jessica Engebretsen was looking for her mother Sherry and says she remembers the last time she talked to her.
Last night, at 5:39, my mom called home and said she's on her way.
When I put this bottle on my table, I feel free.
I feel - yeah, free man.
